learning_outcomes.description: Respect research ethics and apply ethical standards in economic research.
Classify, organise and evaluate literature in economics.
Communicate research idea effectively to an educated audience.

assessments.task_description:
Students are to state and classify an economic research question of their choice, and list at least three (3) permissible bibliography items relating to the question stated. A detailed annotation is required for the first bibliographic item listed. A brief annotation is required for each of the other two bibliographic items.

A template is provided on the course Blackboard site for students to complete this assessment.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit electronically to Turnitin via the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Building upon their annotated bibliography, students are to submit their own research proposal in the form of a written research proposal template. In the proposal, students should:

  1. State and classify their research question;
  2. Describe the significance and innovation of their proposal relative to the literature;
  3. Describe the methods they would like to use to answer their question; and
  4. Outline the expected benefits from their proposed research.

A template is provided on the course Blackboard site for students to complete this assessment.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit electronically to Turnitin via the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Reflection (10%)

Students are to reflect upon a presentation in the Week 13 Lecture, and identify one (1) improvement they can make on their own presentation.

A template will be provided on the Course Blackboard site for students to complete this part of the assessment.

Video Proposal (15%)

Having considered the potential improvement based on their reflection, students will make a 3-minute video pitching their research proposal to a specialised audience.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines:
Reflection: Submit electronically to Turnitin via the course Blackboard site.
Video: Submit electronically to Blackboard Assignment via the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
